(สกลนคร) is a town in the

value: File:Phra That Choeng Chum, Sakon Nakhon, Thailand.jpg

Sakon Nakhon is 647 km from Bangkok. It has an area of 9,605 square kilometres, mostly in the Phu Phan mountains. It has many forest temple meditation retreats. 

Sakon Nakhon is a Buddhist town with five Buddhist stupas. Its history dates back three thousand years. Legend says that Nongharn town, or presently Sakon Nakhon, was built in 11th century when the Khmer ruled this region. When the Khmer lost their power, the town was under the rules of Lanxang or Laotian Kingdom. It was renamed “Muang Chiang Mai Nongharn”. When the town joined Siam, it was renamed again as “Sakon Thavapi”. In 1830, during the reign of King Rama III, it was renamed “Sakon Nakhon”.

A mix of Thai and Lao is spoken in Sakon Nakhon. Central Thai is perfectly acceptable. There are few expats living in the city and few foreign visitors, so don't expect much in the way of spoken English or English translations beyond road signs, though locals will do their best to help you with whatever English they know. That being said, it's advisable to dive headfirst into learning the dialect and start mixing with the locals.

, take Hwy 2 to Saraburi and turn right onto Hwy 2, via Nakhon Ratchasima, Ban Phai of Khon Kaen Province to Ban Tha Phra. Get onto Hwy 23 via Maha Sarakham and Kalasin, then use Hwy 213 to Sakon Nakhon. (7-9 hr respecting speed limits)
and private bus companies operate daily service from Bangkok to Sakon Nakhon. Buses leave the Northeast Bus Terminal (Mo Chit 2) daily.

, where tourists can catch a bus to Sakon Nakhon, 159 km away (3-4 hours, 100 baht, air-con. Buses going to

may stop in Sakon Nakhon). The night train from Bangkok usually departs at 20:00, and is supposed to reach Udon Thani around 06:00 (more likely 09:00). Around 1,000 baht for a soft bed in a 2-bed first-class cabin with air-con.)

value: File:Sakon Nakhon Airport main building exterior.JPG

flys from Bangkok to Sakon Nakhon for around 3,500 baht one-way.
(200-1,300 baht one-way in 2013), and  flights from Bangkok to

(200-1,300 baht one-way in 2013).

In Udon Thani, tourists can catch a bus to Sakon Nakhon, 159 km away (3-4 hours, 100 baht (2010), buses going to Nakhon Phanom and Mukdahan may stop in Sakon Nakhon).

You can get around by bus, samlor, and motored tricycle that are available in the city. Fare is negotiated.

There is no real rental shop for tourists, but you can arrange in almost any motorcycle shop a daily rental for around 100-200 baht, or monthly for 1,500-2,000 baht.

value: content=Communities from around the Sakon Nakhon province spend a considerable amount of time (and money) constructing large model Buddhist temples out of wax.  These impressive models are loaded onto trailers and driven through the city during the annual wax castle parade.  It draws quite a large number of Thai tourists, and a few expats as well, but is still relatively unknown to foreign tourists.  The parade takes place at the end of Buddhist Lent (or ook-pansa in Thai). As Buddhist Lent is according to the lunar calendar, it is held in October but not on the same day each year.
directions=30 km south of sakon nakhon on 2339 road

content=The reservoir is a part of Huai Huat National Park, a consequence of Huai Huat Dam construction. Fronting the reservoir are a royal hall, a flower garden, and a natural arrangement of various forms of rocks.
directions=45km west of Sakon Nakhon on Rte 22 to Udon Thani, then 8 km south on Phang Khon-Waritchaphum road
content=Huge dam provides a sanctuary for numerous teals. A trip to Mae Un Waterfall and a fishing trip are some examples of various activities at the dam.
content=A multipurpose dam. 172 m long and 40 m high, it dams up a huge lake with a surface area of about 6,000 acres.
content= A 32 sq km lake in Sakon Nakhon is a popular place of relaxation. Its offshore isles, particularly the Don Sawan, are both beautiful and restful and can be easily reached by hired boats.
directions=25 kilometres on Sakon Nakhon-Kalasin Rte 213
content=The park is scattered with limestone mountains, groves, and savannahs with several natural attractions such as Tat Ton Waterfall and Kham Hom Waterfall.

content=Songkran is Thailand's traditional New Years from the 13-15 Apr annually. Do not think Songkran is just for the big cities as seemingly the entire town comes out to play for several days of water throwing madness. It is about the best fun you can have in Sakon. Most of the action takes place from the temple Wat Phra That Choeng Chum and several blocks to the northwest.
A large Teco-Lotus superstore in Sakon Nakon. One has to pass a checkpoint before entering the premises.
directions=Corner of Khu Mueang Rd and Jai Pah Suk Rd
content=General shopping. There's also a food court, a MK Restaurant and even a decent sushi stand.

content=Primarily a vegetable market, but you can also buy some cheap clothes (especially at night when the market expands to the opposite side of the street) and other odds-and-ends. It's also a great place to pick up a quick Thai meal in a plastic bag.

content=Excellent little steak house. English menus.

content=Delicious range of Thai/Isaan/French/international cuisine with menu in English, air-con, English spoken, nice set of international desserts.
directions=Ban Tha Rae, north of Nong Han Lake on the road to Nakhon Phanom

content=Dog meat is sold to those meat-eaters desperate to taste sour and spicy dog-bone soup, peppery dog meat salad, or dark spicy smoked dog sausage. Gourmets say the meat is particularly succulent and tastes like deer. They order it fried or boiled. Dog oil is said to be a useful ointment second to none when it comes to cure scratches or burned skin. The thought of eating dog horrifies most Thais and the promotion of canine cuisine is not something the Tourism Authority of Thailand is keen to support.
directions=Rat Phatthana Rd, opposite the city's main bus terminal

content=A modern bakery and restaurant. Sells Thai and Western meals. Popular with expats and foreigners also because it's one of the few restaurants that has an English language menu and air-con. 17.158889, 104.142778
directions=15 km southeast of Sakon Nakhon on Rte 223 between the military camp and Non Hom town

content=Cute traditional northeastern-style guesthouse 5 minutes from Sakon Nakhon airport, with a beautiful garden and landscaping. Jasmin and fragrant flowers, orchids, spa, sauna, Jacuzzi. Wi-Fi, satellite TV. English spoken, Breakfast included, latte, cappuccini, meals to go, motorbike rental
price=300 baht per day; 3,000 baht per month.
content=All rooms are fully furnished. 26 inch LCD TV, water heater, cable TV, 24 hour security, laundry service.
